United States Department of State / Foreign relations of the United States : diplomatic papers, 1945. General : the United Nations
			(1945)

 The United Nations conference on international organization, San Francisco, California, April 25-June 26, 1945, pp. 1-1432
			
 PDF (565.5 MB) 



Page 1319


UNITED NAMON& .WNFERENCE
 MR. STAssER said that a decision was still needed on Mr. Rolin's
proposal for a two-thirds vote for the'rati~eation of amendments
rather than a -majority of the states other than the five permanent
members an the Security Council. A BASSADQR HAmFAx said it would
be his pleasure to have the Ambassador &gree with the rest of the
group so that they could all go along together in accepting Mr. Rolin's
proposal. If this was not possible,; he said! his second, pleasuro was
to be free on this point to move as the delegations desired. He did
not believe it was a point of great subtauce and he believed that the
delegations could agree to differ on it. t
 AimBASSAOR GRoMYKo asked.why-we had to make three important
concessions at one time.
 SENATOR CONNALLY urged that we were not taking these positions
for ourselves but in order to make it possible to secure the veto that
we had to have-on amendments. This veto,-he said, was the insides
of this thing-the whole works. It was the liver, the stomach, the
heart, and the lungs, and if we could not- get it+ -the whole proposition
would blow up. He pointed out that in Comrmittee III/1 we had
obtained acceptance of -the Yalta formula 77 only after the most la-
borious, sweaty and almost bloody fight. We were not making these
proposals now for the sake of others, he said, but foir ourselves. We
needed to continue to hold thejdriver's rein and, if we did not go along
on some of these, matters, we would lose the driver's seat. Where
would we be, he asked, if we did not get the veto on amendments?
AMBASSADOR GROMyKO indicated that he 'Would agree not to oppose
Mr. Rolin's proposal.
 MR. STEmxNs said it would now be possible to end our consulta-
tions on this question also, with each delegation free to act on all
three points as it saw fit.
 -SENATOR CONNALLY then rose and went over to shake Ambasador
Gromyko'd hand, commenting that he thought it would be appropriate
at this time to pause in order to baptize Ambassador Gromyko.
 N.' SsmNius announced that there was still up for'discussion
the draft on interim arrangements and that Ambassador Gromyko
also wished to discuss the question of the right of the Assembly to
discuss any matter within the sphere of international relations. He
suggested that Mr. Dulles introduce that latter problem.
 MNR. DuwLis said that he understood this question was being raised
on behalf of the Soviet Government which had not been satisfied with
the text adopted by Comnittee II/2 providing that: "The.General
Ajsemblyshould have the right to discuss any~matter within the sphere
"Doc. 967, III/1/48, June 14, UNCIO Documents, sol. 11, p, 518.
